Erik Wilde (@dret): Linksets: Links as First Class Citizens

(2) Summary

Web Links play a central role in RESTful Web architecture and hypermedia. A new draft proposes a way to represent Web Links as standalone documents, and introduces two media types and one link relation for this new type of Web resource. This presentation presents the rationale and the design, and in essence is a request for community feedback.

5 in 5: Links as First Class Citizens Erik Wilde (@dret): Linksets: Links as First Class Citizens

(7) Web Linking Changes

  • PSA: Web Linking is under revision
    • RFC 5988 [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988] has been around for almost 7 years
    • draft-nottingham-rfc5988bis [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-nottingham-rfc5988bis] will replace RFC 5988 very soon
  • No major changes to the existing specification
    • No more Link Relation Application Data Registry
    • Many tweaks and clarifications of the existing model [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-nottingham-rfc5988bis#appendix-C]


5 in 5: Links as First Class Citizens Erik Wilde (@dret): Linksets: Links as First Class Citizens

(8) Links as Resources

  • Scenario 1: Third-Party Links
    • Better support for service orchestration (LaaS)
  • Scenario 2: Challenges Writing to HTTP Header Field
    • Applications may have challenges serializing links in header fields
  • Scenario 3: Large Number of Links
    • HTTP header fields are constrained in size and should not be too big
    • Link resources enable link-oriented features such as paging and searching


5 in 5: Links as First Class Citizens Erik Wilde (@dret): Linksets: Links as First Class Citizens

(9) Linkset Design

  • Native and JSON representation of Web Links
    • Native is the HTTP Link header field syntax
    • JSON is based on native but easier to process with a standard JSON toolset
  • Unconstrained representation of Web Links
    • Any Web Link data can be represented in both syntaxes
  • Schema-agnostic representation of Web Links
    • No schema knowledge about non-standard target attributes is required


5 in 5: Links as First Class Citizens Erik Wilde (@dret): Linksets: Links as First Class Citizens

(10) Linkset Media Types

  • Native representation based on the HTTP Link header field syntax
    • Requires specialized parsing
    • Requires character escaping for non-ASCII characters
  • JSON representation uses JSON to encode the native information model
    • Can be processed with any JSON toolset
    • Requires some transcoding for non-ASCII characters
[ { "href"   : "http://example.com/foo", 
    "rel   " : [ "next" ] } ]
  • linkset-simple.json
[ { "href"   : "http://example.com/foo",
    "rel"    : [ "next" ],
    "title"  : "naechstes Kapitel",
    "title*" : [ [ "nÃ¤chstes Kapitel", "de" ] ],
    "foo"    : [ "foovalue" ],
    "bar"    : [ "barone", "bartwo" ] } ]
  • linkset-extension.json


5 in 5: Links as First Class Citizens Erik Wilde (@dret): Linksets: Links as First Class Citizens

(11) Check and Comment

  • Check out the current Linkset Internet Draft [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-wilde-linkset]
    1. application/linkset media type for the native representation
    2. application/linkset+json media type for the JSON representation
    3. linkset link relation for linking to link sets
  • Did we miss any interesting use cases?
    • Affordances without data! That's oddâ¦ or maybe useful?
    • Is there a typical data/control ratio in REST design?
